Description: This photograph captures a somber interior of a room at the Hudson River State Hospital, emphasizing the lingering remnants of its past. Two wooden chairs, positioned opposite each other, dominate the foreground, their surfaces dusty and showing signs of neglect. The faded pink walls are visible, marred by extensive peeling paint that reveals patches of cracked, light-colored undertones. Above, a small rectangular window with a metal mesh grille allows limited light to filter into the room, contributing to the overall dim atmosphere. The lower part of the walls shows staining and deterioration, likely from moisture, while the flooring is littered with debris, including broken wood and remnants of what may have been furniture or fixtures. This setting exudes a sense of abandonment and decay, underlined by the absence of any signs of life or human presence. The color palette is subdued, dominated by faded pinks and grays with hints of brown from the chairs. Dust particles float in the rays of light, enhancing the desolate feel. The overall tone of the image is haunting, evoking a reflection on the passage of time and the history of the location. Keywords: Hudson River State Hospital, abandoned room, psychiatric hospital, decay, historical documentation, interior photography, furniture, peeling paint, neglect.

Description: This image features a derelict interior of Hudson River State Hospital, showcasing two stained glass windows framed in crumbling walls. The left window has vibrant red, blue, and yellow glass segments arranged in a geometric pattern, while the right window, similarly colored, shows signs of disrepair with sections of the frame missing. Surrounding the windows, the walls are peeling, with large patches of faded blue paint and exposed plaster. Vertical water stains mar the surface, suggesting prolonged moisture damage. The windows remain untouched by external elements, but the surrounding structure is deteriorating with visible cracks and flaking paint. The floor appears to contain debris, with the remnants of furniture possibly scattered about. Light filtering through the stained glass casts colored reflections on the cracked and discolored wood framework beneath. The atmosphere is somber, with muted color tones influencing the perception of decay and abandonment. Keywords: historical documentation, Hudson River State Hospital, stained glass windows, architectural decay, vintage interior, historical site, mental health facility, urban exploration.

Description: This image depicts a low flow outlet situated in a desolate area, surrounded by a rugged, overgrown landscape characteristic of the Hudson River State Hospital grounds. The foreground features a reflective pool of still water, showcasing debris floating on the surface, including twigs and fallen leaves. To the left, a rusted metal structure, likely part of the outlet system, protrudes from the ground, standing on decaying wooden supports. Moss has formed on the exposed rocks and waterway edges, indicating a long period of neglect. The ground is covered in a blanket of dried leaves, hinting at the changing seasons, while sparse vegetation attempts to reclaim the space. In the background, a steep incline covered in rocks and branches ascends into a line of barren trees, casting shadows over the water's reflection. Some sections of the hillside have fallen and are littered with natural debris, contributing to the overall sense of abandonment. The image has a muted color palette, dominated by browns and grays, reflecting the decaying nature of the surroundings. Keywords: Hudson River State Hospital, low flow outlet, abandoned site, environmental documentation, decay, water reflection, overgrowth, spring foliage, historical record, neglect.

Description: This image presents the front elevation of a building on the Hudson River State Hospital campus, showcasing its architectural features and surrounding environment. The structure, primarily clad in pale siding, displays multiple windows adorned with blue shutters, a color that has started to fade. The main entrance features a small, covered porch supported by two columns. The roof is pitched, with asphalt shingles that appear worn but largely intact. A neatly paved walkway leads up to the entrance, though it shows signs of wear with cracks and patches of grass pushing through. The foreground is primarily grassy, with scattered wildflowers, suggesting neglect but not total abandonment. To either side, sparse tree growth can be observed, indicating some level of overgrowth but leaving the structure fairly visible. The sky overhead is partly cloudy, casting diffused light over the scene, providing a softer color palette that highlights the building's aging elements. Small patches of peeling paint are visible, particularly around the window frames and porch area. No obvious signs of graffiti or vandalism are present, contributing to a sense of relative tranquility despite the evident aging of the structure. Keywords: historic site, psychiatric hospital, architectural documentation, conservation, rural decay, faded colors, overgrown landscaping, neglected pathways.

Description: This image documents the exterior of a building within Hudson River State Hospital, captured in a now-abandoned state. The photograph shows a two-story brick structure with a distinctive pitched roof. The building features multiple windows with a combination of square and rectangular shapes, many exhibiting signs of neglect, such as grime and potential water damage. The porch area showcases wooden railings and columns, hinting at once being a welcoming entry point. A faded white van is parked in front, suggesting past usage or recent visits for documentation purposes. Surrounding the building is a lightly overgrown grass area, contributing to an overall sense of abandonment. The sky is overcast, resulting in a monochrome palette that emphasizes the starkness of the scene. The bricks display some discoloration and fading, indicative of the passage of time. The overall tone is somber, reflecting the historical significance and dilapidated condition of the site. Keywords: psychiatric hospital, architectural history, abandoned site, historic preservation, neglect, overgrown landscape, Poughkeepsie, New York.

Description: This image depicts the Snow Terrace building of the now-closed Hudson River State Hospital, showcasing its architectural features as they appear in 2021. The structure is characterized by a combination of red brick and white siding, typical of early 20th-century institutional architecture. The asphalt surface, which was once likely a busy pathway, appears cracked and worn with patches of vegetation encroaching along the edges. The building's roof features a distinct gabled design, with one side showcasing a peaked section that is bordered by shingles in varying states of deterioration. Notably, several windows on the front facade are boarded up, indicating possible abandonment or renovation efforts that have not been completed. Above the main entrance, a sign that reads 'Snow Terrace' is visibly affixed, with the arrow directing attention towards the structure. The surrounding landscape includes overgrown shrubs and mature trees, suggesting a rewilding effect as nature reclaims the area. The sky overhead is blue with few clouds, providing a stark contrast to the muted tones of the building materials. Overall, the image conveys a sense of historical significance and the passage of time, as the building stands in a state of decay yet retains architectural integrity. Keywords: Hudson River State Hospital, Snow Terrace, architectural features, red brick, white siding, boarded windows, institutional history, decay, historical documentation, Poughkeepsie.

B. Associated with the lives of persons significant in our past.

components may lack individual distinction.

D. Have yielded, or may be likely to yield information important in prehistory or history.

Description: This image provides a detailed view of the decaying structures within the Hudson River State Hospital campus, showcasing the impacts of time and neglect. The photograph captures several buildings designed under the Kirkbride Plan, characterized by their long, linear architecture with ornate details that have begun to deteriorate significantly. The brick façades of the buildings exhibit signs of fading and weathering, with areas where the brick has crumbled or become discolored, revealing the underlying material. Broken windows punctuate the façade, with some frames missing entirely, allowing light to flood into the dark interiors. A nearby structure displays extensive peeling paint, while the roofs show signs of sagging, hinting at possible water damage inside. Grass and weeds have overtaken the walkways and yard, symbolizing nature's reclamation of the land. Overgrown vegetation obscures some of the lower levels, further contributing to the abandoned atmosphere. The sky is partly cloudy, adding a somber feel to the scene. The overall color palette is muted, with earthy tones dominating, suggesting a long history of neglect and decay. Keywords: Hudson River State Hospital, historic architecture, Kirkbride Plan, decay, urban exploration, psychiatric hospital, abandoned site, natural reclamation, weathering, historical documentation.

Description: This black-and-white photograph showcases the exterior of Hudson River State Hospital, emphasizing its architectural features and the state of the buildings as of 2021. The image captures a long, two-story brick structure characterized by a series of arched openings that once served as porches. Each arch is lined by a simple railing, indicative of the Kirkbride Plan's design philosophy, which aimed to balance aesthetics with functionality. The brickwork appears in solid condition, with its deep red hue contrasting against the desaturated colors typical of older photographs. The building on the right features a prominent entrance with classical columns, though the details are slightly softened due to age. A streetlight can be seen at the forefront, standing alone on a pathway that meanders towards the building's entrance. There are signs of neglect, as the surrounding grass appears unkempt and overgrown. Although no graffiti is visible in this image, the area around the buildings shows potential signs of vandalism elsewhere. The overall tone of the photograph is somber and historical, reflecting both the building's significance and its current state of abandonment. Keywords: Hudson River State Hospital, architectural heritage, Kirkbride Plan, historical significance, abandonment, brick architecture, vintage photography, decay.

results.content:
- GAG

AI IMAGE DESCRIPTION (v0.2.2): 
            The following description was provided by an Artificial Intelligence (GPT-4o by OpenAI).
            It may not be fully accurate. Its purpose is to provide keywords and context
            so that the document can be more easily searched.
            Suggested Title: Interior of Avery Chapel - HRSH Documentation
            Inferred Date: None
            Suggested Tags: ['building interior', 'graffiti']
            Previous Title: HRSH Documentation Pic - Avery Chapel - Pulpit
            Previous Date: 2025-02-11
        

Description: This image depicts the interior of Avery Chapel at Hudson River State Hospital, showcasing decay and abandonment. The foreground features a rusted folding chair positioned on a damaged tiled floor, littered with dust and debris, indicating years of neglect. The floor tiles exhibit a mix of worn red and black squares, with some sections entirely missing or crumbling away. In the background, the pulpit area is visible, constructed from dark wood and showing signs of deterioration, including peeling paint and water damage to the wall behind it, revealing layers of old wallpaper. A wooden lectern stands in front of the pulpit, slightly askew, neglected amid the debris. The walls are stark, with patches of peeling plaster, and the remnants of blue paint are visible, adding a ghostly atmosphere to the setting. The overall color tone is dreary, with muted browns, grays, and blues dominating the scene, emphasizing the chapel's forlorn condition. Signs of decay are prevalent, including broken woodwork and the absence of glass in windows, contributing to the somber feel of the space. Keywords: Hudson River State Hospital, Avery Chapel, interior decay, furniture, architectural deterioration, historical documentation, abandoned space, chapel, psychiatric hospital.

custom_fields.value: License offered by Jess Mann to anyone on this site.

results.content:
| LABORATORY UpstaiRs
NO ADmit:

AI IMAGE DESCRIPTION (v0.2.2): 
            The following description was provided by an Artificial Intelligence (GPT-4o by OpenAI).
            It may not be fully accurate. Its purpose is to provide keywords and context
            so that the document can be more easily searched.
            Suggested Title: Interior of Morgue - Hudson River State Hospital
            Inferred Date: None
            Suggested Tags: ['building interior']
            Previous Title: Morge Trays - LeftRight
            Previous Date: 2025-02-11
        

Description: This image depicts the interior of the morgue area at the now-closed Hudson River State Hospital. The prominent feature is a set of metal morgue trays, which are visible through the open compartments of a large, rusted structure. The trays appear old and worn, showing signs of corrosion and neglect. To the left, a wooden door labeled 'LABORATORY UPSTAIRS NO ADMITTANCE' retains its original doorknob but is painted a dull white, with noticeable scratches and peeling paint indicating that it has not been maintained. The walls surrounding the morgue trays exhibit significant wear, with patches of cracked and peeling paint revealing the underlying layer. A length of electrical cord, coiled and hanging on the wall, suggests previous operational use. The flooring is tiled, now dirty and scattered with debris, contributing to an overall impression of abandonment. The lighting in the room is dim, with a faint green hue emanating from a doorway in the background, hinting at further decay and disuse in that direction. Elements of environmental decay—such as rust, grime, and detached wall tiles—are prevalent throughout the scene. Keywords: historical documentation, abandoned hospital interior, morgue, decay, psychiatric facility, rust, peeling paint, vintage medical architecture, urban exploration.
results.title: Morge Trays - LeftRight

Description: This image showcases a contrasting view of a decaying door and the morgue trays at Hudson River State Hospital. The left side features an aged wooden door, painted in faded blue, with significant peeling paint and visible cracks. The door's texture highlights its abandonment, with a round doorknob that appears tarnished and worn. On the right side, a morgue tray is partially visible through an opened door of a metal cabinet, showcasing rusted edges and dark recesses, indicative of neglect. The interior walls are tiled in white, yet they too show signs of wear and discoloration. The overall lighting is dim, enhancing the eerie atmosphere associated with the abandoned space. The floor beneath is tiled, but its condition is obscured by shadows. The image encapsulates the somber history of the hospital, with elements of decay, disrepair, and the passage of time evident throughout. Keywords: Hudson River State Hospital, morgue, decay, abandonment, historical documentation, metal cabinet, peeling paint, architectural details.

Summary: The document is a blueprint detailing the layout of the Hudson River State Hospital in Poughkeepsie, New York. It illustrates the structural design, including various wards and rooms within the facility, and showcases the Kirkbride Plan architecture. Key elements include a number of specified rooms, dimensions, and organizational flow of the hospital's design.

Content: The blueprint includes sections labeled with room names and dimensions, indicating specific wards and their layouts. It is printed on blue paper with white ink, typical of blueprints, and displays a highly technical design format. The tone is architectural and procedural, emphasizing the structural organization of the building. The document is a printed blueprint with no handwritten annotations or alterations. Institutional markings may include the name of the hospital and potential codes used in the original architectural design. Additional keywords relevant for categorization include architecture, facility layout, psychiatric hospital, Kirkbride Plan, historical design.

Description: This image presents a close-up view of three glass objects resting on a deteriorating wooden table. The objects are circular with a dark brown rim, appearing to be small glass holders or containers, possibly once used for decorative purposes. Their clarity is somewhat obscured by dust and grime, highlighting years of neglect. The table surface is marred by scratches and peeling paint, and various debris is scattered around, including small bits of broken glass and flakes of paint. The background is slightly blurred but reveals elements of a derelict room, with empty space suggesting the absence of furniture and neglect. The color tones in the image are muted, dominated by grays and browns, evoking a sense of decay and abandonment. Remnants of peeling wallpaper and damaged surfaces can be faintly discerned, indicating moisture damage. Overall, the scene reflects a once-utilized space that has fallen into disrepair, encapsulating a moment of historical significance. Keywords: Hudson River State Hospital, abandoned objects, decay, glassware, historical documentation, deteriorating surfaces, urban exploration.

Summary: This document is a calendar for January 1987 from the Hudson River Psychiatric Center's Employees Federal Credit Union. It includes office hours and contact information for the credit union as well as holidays recognized during the month, such as Martin Luther King Jr. Day. The calendar appears aged and damaged, reflecting its time within the hospital environment.

Content: The calendar showcases the days of January 1987, with notable dates like the 19th, marked as Martin Luther King Jr. Day. It lists business hours (9 A.M. to 4 P.M., Monday through Friday) for the federal credit union. The document is printed but shows signs of deterioration, including stains and torn edges. The tone is neutral and informative, typical of utility calendars. Official markings include the name of the credit union and contact information. The physical state of the document shows considerable wear, indicative of its abandonment. Keywords include: calendar, credit union, office hours, January.

Summary: This document is a greeting card expressing well wishes for recovery following surgery. It emphasizes hope for a swift healing process and encourages the recipient by stating that the operation is now a thing of the past. The tone is warm and supportive, indicative of personal correspondence.

Content: The card features the following message:
"Thinking of you and hoping
Your recovery will be fast
Now that your operation
Is simply 'a thing of the past'
Hoping you'll improve so much
With each and every day
That it won't be long before you feel
Just fine in every way."

The card appears to be a printed greeting with handwritten cursive text. The document is slightly worn with some stains and signs of aging, giving it a vintage feel. There are no visible stamps or official markings, and it is a single folded card without any anomalies. Keywords for searchability include 'recovery,' 'surgery,' 'greeting card,' 'well wishes,' 'personal correspondence.'
